content.text: Explain what is meant by the accuracy of a measured value
Show that the calculated density of the material of cube A is \(8.7 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the density of the material of cube A
The density of the material of cube B is determined to be \(9.2 \times 10^{3} \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3} \pm 6\%\)
State and explain whether cube A and cube B could be made from the same material
Two solid cubes, A and B, are measured to determine the density of their materials
Table 1.1 shows the measurements for cube A
State the principle of moments
By taking moments about end A, determine the distance \(x\) from A to P
The bottom of the cylinder is submerged in the water to depth \(y\) as shown in Fig. 2.2. The beam is still attached to the cylinder but not shown
The cylinder has mass \(11\mathrm{kg}\) and diameter \(0.78\mathrm{m}.\) The beam exerts a vertical force of \(1300\mathrm{N}\) on the cylinder. The cylinder is in equilibrium
Show that the upthrust acting on the cylinder is \(1400\mathrm{N}.\)
The water has density \(990\mathrm{kg}\mathrm{m}^{- 3}.\)
Calculate the depth \(y.\)
The person can stand anywhere between A and B
On Fig. 2.3, sketch the variation of the depth of the bottom of the cylinder with the distance of the person from A, for distances between 0 and 6.0 m. Numerical values are not required
[Total: 10]
A solid plastic cylinder floats in water. It is used to support one end of a horizontal uniform beam AB as shown in Fig. 2.1
The beam has length \(6.0 \text{m}\) and weight \(1700 \text{N}\). The beam is attached to solid ground with a hinge at end A

The cylinder is floating vertically in the water. The top of the cylinder is attached at its centre to the beam at a horizontal distance of \(5.0 \text{m}\) from end A. The cylinder applies a vertical force of \(1300 \text{N}\) to the beam
A person of weight \(660 \text{N}\) stands on the beam at point P
The beam AB is in equilibrium
Calculate the acceleration of the truck between A and B
Determine the gain in kinetic energy of the truck between A and B
A truck R of mass \(9400\mathrm{kg}\) moves with constant acceleration in a straight line down a slope, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1
At point A the speed of the truck is \(13\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) and at point B the speed of the truck is \(22\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) . A and B are a distance of \(180\mathrm{m}\) apart
Define force
Show that the average resultant force \(F\) acting on truck R between time \(t = 0\) and \(t = 15 \text{s}\) is \(-1.2 \times 10^4 \text{N}\)
An identical truck S has the same initial momentum as truck R. Truck S experiences a constant force equal to the force \(F\) in (b)(ii)
State and explain whether truck S will take more, less or the same amount of time to come to rest as truck R
[Total: 10]

A short time after passing point B truck R moves in a straight line on horizontal ground. The driver of the truck applies the brakes. Fig. 3.2 shows the variation with time of the momentum of the truck
The line XY is perpendicular to the metal sheet. The device emits microwaves of frequency \(6.3 \text{GHz}\)
When the device is at position P, a stationary wave is formed between the device and the sheet
Explain how the stationary wave, including the nodes and the antinodes, is formed
Calculate the wavelength of the microwaves
At point P the receiver detects a maximum amplitude of the stationary wave

The device is moved slowly from point P along the line XY and the receiver detects a series of minimum and maximum amplitudes. The first time a minimum amplitude is detected by the receiver is when the device is at point Q
Determine the distance between P and Q

The intensity of the microwaves emitted by the device is increased. The frequency of the microwaves is unchanged. The device is moved slowly along the line XY from point Q until the next maximum amplitude is detected at point R
State and explain whether the distance QR is greater than, less than or the same as distance PQ
[Total: 8]
A device containing a microwave emitter and receiver is placed in front of a large metal sheet in a vacuum as shown in Fig. 4.1
The time-base of the CRO is set to \(5.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{ s cm}^{-1}\)
The speed of the sound emitted by the loudspeaker is \(330 \text{ m s}^{-1}\)
Determine the wavelength of the sound
The loudspeaker now moves in a straight line while emitting the same sound of constant frequency. The period of the trace on the CRO increases continuously
Describe the motion of the loudspeaker

A stationary loudspeaker emits sound of constant frequency. A microphone is placed near to the loudspeaker and connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO). The trace on the screen of the CRO is shown in Fig. 5.1
Calculate the potential difference between the two ends of the wire
Show that the cross-sectional area of the wire is \(1.3 \times 10^{-6} \text{m}^2\)
Show that the number density of charge carriers in the wire is \(8.3 \times 10^{28} \text{m}^{-3}\)
Calculate the average drift speed of the charge carriers (electrons) in the wire
State and explain how the resistance of wire Q compares with the resistance of wire P
On Fig. 6.3, sketch a graph of the variation of the average drift speed of the charge carriers with distance from end X of wire Q
Fig. 6.3
[Total: 13]
A different copper wire Q has the same volume as wire P, but non-uniform radius, as shown in Fig. 6.2
The radius \(r_1\) at end X of wire Q is the same as the radius of wire P. Radius \(r_2\) is less than \(r_1\)
A cylindrical copper wire P of length \(0.24 \text{m}\) is shown in Fig. 6.1
The current in the wire is \(0.85\mathsf{A}.\)
The resistance of the wire is \(3.3\mathsf{m}\Omega .\)
The total number of charge carriers \(N\) in the wire is \(2.6 \times 10^{22}\)
The resistivity of copper is \(1.8 \times 10^{-8} \Omega \cdot \text{m}\)
Complete the equation for this decay
By considering momentum, calculate the speed of nucleus R after the decay
State **three** quantities that are conserved during the decay
[Total: 7]
An isolated stationary nucleus Q decays into nucleus R and an \(\alpha\) -particle. The \(\alpha\) -particle has speed \(1.5 \times 10^{7} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\)
